learning_outcomes.description: Demonstrate knowledge of the causes (and potential regulatory solutions) of climate change.
Understand and apply economic concepts to the issue of climate change.
Critically evaluate the economic outcome of climate change policy.
Communicate economic thinking in non-technical, plain language via different formats.

assessments.task_description:
Student IDs are mandatory. Students must present a valid university-issued ID card to be admitted into the room for the quiz. Without it, entry will not be permitted.

Students are required to complete three in-class quizzes covering the materials

  • Students will have 30 minutes to complete each quiz.
  • There will be true/false, multiple choice, and numerical questions in this quiz. 
  • Students should be at the venue for your quiz on time in the weeks of assessment. You must attend your allocated tutorial.
  • If you arrive late to the session, you will not receive additional time to complete the quiz.
  • The quizzes allow one (1) typed double sided A4 Page Cheat Sheet with standard margins, 1.5 line spacing minimum, and 12pt Font Size (Times New Roman or Calibri Fonts Required). All notes MUST be in English. Cheat Sheets must be handed in with your quiz at time for submission. This will be checked and non-compliance with these requirements accounts for academic misconduct.
  • Only UQ approved calculators are allowed.
  • More details regarding the format of the quiz will be posted to Blackboard under Assessment.


This assessment task evaluates students' abilities, skills and knowledge without the aid of generative Artificial Intelligence (AI). Students are advised that the use of AI technologies to develop responses is strictly prohibited and may constitute student misconduct under the Student Code of Conduct.

assessments.task_description:
Students will be required to design an infographic on an issue relating to the first 7 weeks of course content on climate economics. Students must also record a 3–4-minute presentation on the infographic explaining the purpose and analysis provided by the infographic. It is required that students are physically and clearly visible in the recording. We recommend using Zoom or Teams to record your infographic presentation. 

Please See Blackboard for specific question, details, and criteria.

This task has been designed to be challenging, authentic and complex. Whilst students may use AI and/or MT technologies, successful completion of assessment in this course will require students to critically engage in specific contexts and tasks for which artificial intelligence will provide only limited support and guidance.

A failure to reference generative AI use may constitute student misconduct under the Student Code of Conduct.

To pass this assessment, students will be required to demonstrate detailed comprehension of their written submission independent of AI tools.

assessments.late_submission: A penalty of 10% of the maximum possible mark will be deducted per 24 hours from time submission is due for up to 7 days. After 7 days, you will receive a mark of 0.

assessments.task_description:
As part of the policy brief, students are expected to conduct through research on the selected policy issue, analyse the economic aspects of the policy issue and use economic graphs to illustrate key relationships, trends or comparisons.

  • Page Limit: 1 page (single-sided).
  • A maximum two graphs, tables, or other illustrations in total can be provided on a second page.
  • Margin Size: Minimum of a 1.5cm margins on all sides. Smaller margins will result in a penalty.
  • Font Size: Use a legible font size 11-point such as Times New Roman, Calibri or Arial.
  • Line Spacing: Minimum single line spacing
